senses.de: An amount of something that balances, cancels, or compensates for something else.
senses.ex: The increased cost of fuel was offset by the decrease in maintenance costs.

Tips.title: Balancing Act
Tips.description: When offset is used as a noun, it often refers to something that equals out another, creating balance.
Tips.example: The earnings from the bake sale acted as an offset to the club's previous expenses.

Tips.title: Financial Context
Tips.description: Offset is commonly used in financial situations to talk about balancing costs and benefits.
Tips.example: We must find an offset for the extra spending on new equipment.

senses.de: To balance, counteract, or compensate for something.
senses.ex: His speed is offset by his lack of accuracy.

Tips.title: Action Result
Tips.description: As a verb, offset implies an action taken to create balance or to reduce an effect.
Tips.example: Planting trees may offset carbon emissions from driving cars.

Tips.title: Cause and Effect
Tips.description: Offset as a verb suggests that one thing will make up for or neutralize another thing.
Tips.example: The scholarship will offset the cost of tuition for many students.

senses.de: In printing, offset is a method where an image is transferred to a plate, then to rubber, then to the printing surface.
senses.ex: Offset printing provides a high quality of print and it is cost effective when used for a large number of prints.

Tips.title: Printing Method
Tips.description: Offset in the printing context refers to a specific process used to create high-quality printed materials.
Tips.example: Magazines are often printed using the offset method for better image reproduction.

Tips.title: Reproduction Quality
Tips.description: The term 'offset' in printing is associated with mass production and professional quality.
Tips.example: Offset printing is preferred for high-volume orders like newspapers.

senses.de: In architecture, an offset is a change in direction of a building material or a set-back or step in a wall's face.
senses.ex: The offset in the building's brickwork creates a distinct visual contrast.

Tips.title: Visual Dynamics
Tips.description: In architecture, an offset is not just structural but also adds visual interest to a building.
Tips.example: The architect designed an offset in the facade for a modern look.

senses.de: In automotive design, the distance from the mounting surface of an undriven wheel to the rim's centerline.
senses.ex: A wrong wheel offset could cause problems with how your car handles.

Tips.title: Wheel Alignment
Tips.description: Automotive offset affects how the wheels sit and can influence handling and performance.
Tips.example: The mechanic adjusted the offset to improve the steering.

Tips.title: Safe Driving
Tips.description: The correct offset in cars is critical for safe and stable driving conditions.
Tips.example: Choosing the right offset ensures the car does not rub against the wheel well.

Balance.wordDefinition:
Balance refers to the stability of something or the even distribution of weight or resources. For example, if you have two weights on a scale, you need to balance them so that they are equal and the scale is level.

In financial terms, balance can refer to having an equal amount of money on both sides of a ledger, which means expenses and revenue should match.

Offset refers to a counterbalancing effect or compensation for something. For example, if you want to offset the carbon emissions from your car, you can plant trees, which absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

Balance is about making sure things are equal and stable, while offset is about compensating for something or creating a counterbalancing effect.

You would use balance to ensure fairness or stability, and offset to make up for something, neutralize an effect, or improve something.

Begin.wordDefinition:
Begin means to start something, while the word offset means to counterbalance or compensate for something.

For example, you can use begin when you're starting a project or a conversation.

Begin is used to start something new, while offset is used to counterbalance or compensate for something.

Compensate.wordDefinition:
To compensate means to provide something good or positive to make up for something bad or negative. For example, if a company made a mistake that caused a customer inconvenience, they might compensate the customer by providing a discount or free product.

In general, compensating is used to make up for something negative that has already happened, while offsetting is used to prevent or counteract something negative that may happen in the future.

Counterbalance.wordDefinition:
Counterbalance refers to a weight or force that is used to balance or offset another weight or force. For example, if you have a heavy weight on one side of a teeter-totter, you can add a counterweight to the other side to balance it out.

Counterbalance is used to balance or counteract a weight, while offset is used to compensate or counteract a change in something.

Equalize.wordDefinition:
Equalize means to make things equal or have the same value, while offset means to counterbalance or balance out.

For example, if you have two lengths of rope and you want them to be the same length, you would equalize them by cutting or stretching one to match the other.

Equalize is used when you want to make things even or equal, while offset is used when you need to compensate for something else.

Neutralize.wordDefinition:
Neutralize means to cancel out or eliminate the effect of something completely. For example, if you add an acid to a base, you can neutralize it with an alkaline substance.

Neutralize is used when you want to completely eliminate something, while offset is used when you want to balance something out or minimize its impact.

Set off.wordDefinition:
Offset and set off are two different phrases that have different meanings.

Offset means to counterbalance or compensate for something. For example, if you owe someone money but they owe you money as well, you can say that their debt offsets yours.

Or, if a company emits greenhouse gases, they may offset those emissions by planting trees or investing in renewable energy.

Set off means to start or cause something, often with a sudden or explosive impact. For example, if a car alarm goes off, it sets off a series of loud noises.

Or, if someone's comment makes you angry, it could set off an argument.

Offset is used when talking about balancing or compensating for something, while set off is used when discussing starting or causing something.

Start.wordDefinition:
Start refers to the beginning point of something while offset refers to a shift or deviation from a particular starting point.

For example, if you are measuring the length of a piece of wood, the starting point will be at one end of the wood, while the offset will refer to a distance from that starting point (e.g.

3 inches from the starting point). In programming, start may refer to the beginning of a program or process, while offset may refer to the displacement of data from a particular memory location.

quotes.Text: Nearly everybody I know does something to try to remove herself to clear her head and to have enough time and space to think... All of us instinctively feel that something inside us is crying out for more spaciousness and stillness to offset the exhilarations of this movement and the fun and diversion of the modern world.
quotes.Title: Indian Writer
quotes.Name: Pico Iyer

quotes.Text: We made too many expensive movies trying to offset the loss of the 'LOTR' income. There was a lot of pressure to re-create that franchise, which turned out to be unhealthy for us, because it's such a once-in-a-lifetime success. It would be like trying to re-create 'Avatar' over and over again.
quotes.Title: American Producer
quotes.Name: Toby Emmerich

quotes.Text: Raising the minimum wage represents a substantial financial burden for employers, particularly start-ups, early stage companies, and family-owned businesses. In response, business owners would be forced to either lay off workers or raise prices to offset the rise in labor costs.

quotes.Name: Fabrizio Moreira

quotes.Text: Social safety-net spending is an important form of public funding that helps offset disparities in family resources for children.

quotes.Text: The minimum wage was due for an increase, but it was important that we offset its cost to small businesses.
